data.title: History of Ghosts and Murder Awaits Japan PM in 1929 Mansion
data.meta_description: For the first time in nearly a decade, a Japanese prime minister decided to live in the official residence for the premier -- a century old structure that is a monument to art deco aesthetics and clouded by an ominous history.
data.text:
Shunned home for PM’s to have first resident in nine years

Upkeep of the little-used building cost $1.4 million a year

For the first time in nearly a decade, a Japanese prime minister decided to live in the official residence for the premier -- a century old structure that is a monument to art deco aesthetics and clouded by an ominous history.

On Saturday afternoon Premier Fumio Kishida moved into the two-story 5,183-square-meter (55,789 square foot) stone and brick mansion that was opened in 1929. “It’s been a while since I last moved and I feel fresh,” Kishida told reporters, adding that he made the decision to move to concentrate on official duties.
